Methyl formate (MF) decomposition is essential for producing valuable chemicals, but finding efficient and stable catalysts is challenging. This study explores the catalytic performance of ZnO/AC, K8-10-4/AC, and Zn5K8-10-4/AC in MF decomposition. The catalysts were synthesized by varying the potassium-to-carbon ratios and the calcination temperatures and durations, and characterized using nitrogen adsorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), CO2-TPD, and in-situ DRIFTS. Zn5K8-10-4/AC demonstrated significantly higher activity, with a conversion rate of 99.3%, compared to ZnO/AC (18.4%) and K8-10-4/AC (2.4%) at 210 °C. Potassium addition enhanced the basicity and surface properties, facilitating ester bond cleavage and HCOO species formation. Zn5K8-10-16/AC also exhibited excellent stability over 100 hours, in contrast to the rapid deactivation observed with K8-10-16/AC. This study highlights the synergistic effect of zinc and potassium for improving catalytic performance and stability, offering insights for designing more efficient catalysts for MF decomposition and similar reactions. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Activated carbon Carbon monoxide MF catalytic decomposition Potassium addition Zinc oxide Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Methyl formate (MF), the simplest ester, plays a pivotal role in C1 chemistry as an important intermediate in various chemical processes [1]. Upon decomposition, MF yields methanol (MeOH) and carbon monoxide (CO), both of which are critical feedstocks in the chemical industry. Of particular significance is the coal-to-ethylene glycol process, where MF is both an inherent by-product of carbon monoxide coupling with dimethyl oxalate [2] and a key raw material for CO production. If CO can be efficiently generated through the decomposition of MF, with subsequent recycling of the products, it could significantly reduce costs and improve the overall efficiency of coal-to-ethylene glycol production. Furthermore, the decomposition of MF offers a promising approach for generating CO, a versatile reagent in many chemical processes. This provides a reliable source of in-situ carbon monoxide and carbonyl compounds, which is especially valuable for small- to medium-sized industrial facilities and scientific research [3]. The decomposition kinetics and mechanism of MF have been reported and discussed [4,5]. It was previously reported that the thermal decomposition of MF was a chain reaction [6], while it is generally believed that the thermal decomposition of MF is a set of parallel competitive reactions [7,8]. Over the years, various catalytic systems have been explored to optimize MF decomposition, with a focus on enhancing catalytic activity, selectivity, and stability. The catalysts that have been developed to date include sodium-doped magnesium oxide [9], sodium hydroxide doped magnesium oxide [10], alkali (sodium hydroxide and potassium hydroxide) doped Na-13X and Ca-5A zeolite [11], monovalent, bivalent or trivalent cations exchanged 13X molecular sieve [12], TiO2 supported Pt metal photocatalyst [13] and supported palladium catalyst [14]. Our team has previously developed activated carbon (AC) supported zinc oxide (ZnO) catalysts [15,16] and AC supported palladium catalysts [17]. Among the many catalysts, ZnO has attracted considerable attention due to its favorable catalytic properties. However, the catalytic performance of ZnO alone often falls short in terms of stability and long-term efficiency. Potassium modification of ZnO has shown potential for improving its catalytic performance by enhancing its basicity and modifying its electronic structure. Despite these advances, several challenges remain, particularly in understanding the interaction between potassium and the ZnO surface, as well as in optimizing the stability and selectivity of potassium-modified ZnO catalysts under the harsh reaction conditions typical of MF decomposition. Although potassium-doped catalysts have demonstrated improved activity and selectivity, the mechanisms behind these enhancements are not fully understood. One significant issue is the stability of potassium-modified ZnO catalysts over extended reaction times, as many potassium-based catalysts suffer from deactivation due to sintering or the loss of active sites at high temperatures. This problem is especially pertinent in the case of MF decomposition, which requires elevated temperatures to achieve high reaction rates. Therefore, there remains a need for a deeper understanding of how potassium interacts with ZnO at the atomic level and how these interactions contribute to improved catalytic activity and long-term stability. This study aims to address these challenges by investigating the role of potassium modification in enhancing the catalytic performance and stability of ZnO-based catalysts for MF decomposition. Specifically, we seek to understand how potassium doping alters the electronic structure and surface properties of ZnO, leading to improved adsorption and activation of MF molecules. Furthermore, we will explore the effects of potassium loading and preparation conditions, such as calcination temperature, on the overall catalytic performance. The key scientific questions to be addressed in this research include: (1) How does potassium modification influence the electronic structure of ZnO and its interaction with MF molecules? (2) What is the impact of potassium on the stability of ZnO catalysts under prolonged reaction conditions? and (3) How can the preparation conditions be optimized to achieve the highest catalytic performance and stability for MF decomposition? By addressing these fundamental issues, this research aims to provide insights into the design of more efficient and stable catalysts for MF decomposition, which could have significant industrial implications, especially in the generation of CO and other valuable chemicals from renewable feedstocks. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Potassium hydroxide, zinc nitrate hexahydrate, methyl formate, purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., ltd, China. The AC used is fruit shell AC, its iodine value is 900 mg/g, purchased from Pingdingshan Lvzhiyuan Activated Carbon Co., ltd. 2.2 AC pretreated with KOH aqueous solution A certain mass of KOH and AC was weighed, and the mass ratio of KOH and AC was denoted as α:100-α. Potassium hydroxide was dissolved in deionized water to prepare potassium hydroxide aqueous solution, and then the activated carbon was impregnated into potassium hydroxide solution by equal volume impregnation method for 24 hours, and then it was sent to the oven to dry at 80 °C for 12 hours. The dried sample was taken out and sent to a tube furnace on a porcelain boat for calcination with nitrogen as the protection gas at a calcination temperature of β×100 °C and a calcination time of γ hours. The samples were taken out and dried after cooling in the tube furnace. The resulting sample was designated Kβ-α-γ/AC. 2.3 Preparation of catalysts Aiming at the final theoretical loading of ZnO of 2%, a certain amount of Kβ-α-γ/AC and zinc nitrate hexahydrate were weighed, and zinc nitrate hexahydrate particles were dissolved in water to prepare zinc nitrate aqueous solution. Kβ-α-γ/AC was impregnated in the aqueous solution for 24 hours, and then further dried at 80 °C for 12 hours. The dried sample was calcined in a tube furnace for 4 hours in a nitrogen atmosphere at a calcination temperature of δ×100 °C. After cooling, the sample was taken out and dried for preservation. The prepared catalyst was named ZnδKβ-α-γ/AC. In this experiment, α=0, 5, 10, 15, 20; β=5, 6, 7, 8, 9; γ= 4, 8, 12, 16, 20; δ= 3, 4, 5, 6, 7. 2.4 Characterization of catalysts The surface physical adsorption properties and pore structure of the samples were characterized by ASAP2020 adsorption instrument. The XRD patterns were collected by Rigaku MiniFlex 600 X powder diffractometer. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) images were obtained by G2 F20 field-emission transmission electron microscope. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was collected by ESCALAB 250 Xi photoelectron spectrometer, and Al-Kα was used as the ray source, the obtained data were corrected by the C 1s peak at 284.8 eV. The basic sites on the surface of the samples were characterized by Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 chemical adsorption instrument. 2.5 Catalyst evaluation of catalysts The catalytic activities of the catalyst ware evaluated by a continuous flow fixed bed reactor designed by our research group. MF was injected into the reactor by a pump-propelled syringe with a set propulsion speed, and nitrogen was used as the carrier gas. The samples were analyzed by gas chromatograph equipped with FID (flame ionization detector) and TCD (thermal conductivity detector). The components detected were hydrogen, CO, MF, dimethyl ether and MeOH. The conversion of MF, methanol selectivity and CO selectivity were calculated by the following equations: The calculation of CO selectivity: S C O % = n ( C O ) n ( C O ) + n ( H 2 ) × 100 % The calculation of MeOH selectivity: S M e O H ( % ) = n ( M e O H ) n ( M e O H ) + 2 n ( D M E ) × 100 % The calculation of MF conversion: C o n v . M F ( % ) = n ( M F ) r e a c t e d n ( M F ) f e e d × 100 % 3 Results 3.1 Catalytic performance of catalysts 3.1.1 Performance comparison of ZnO/AC, K8-10-4/AC, and Zn5K8-10-4/AC catalysts for MF decomposition As shown in Table S1, the catalytic activity of activated carbon for MF decomposition is very weak. Besides, as shown in Fig. 1 , the catalytic properties of ZnO/AC, K8-10-4/AC, and Zn5K8-10-4/AC catalysts were compared. The results reveal that under the reaction conditions of 210 °C, the conversion rate of the ZnO/AC catalyst is only 18.4%, while the conversion rate of K8-10-4/AC is merely 2.4%, both exhibiting low catalytic activity. In contrast, the Zn5K8-10-4/AC catalyst, which contains both zinc and potassium, demonstrates excellent catalytic performance, achieving a conversion rate of 99.3%. Moreover, the selectivity of MeOH and CO produced during the decomposition of MF remained relatively consistent across different catalysts. Therefore, it can be concluded that the modification strategy of introducing potassium into the catalyst system effectively enhances catalytic activity. To further explore the impact of preparation conditions on catalytic performance, the study also investigates the influence of varying preparation conditions on catalyst performance. 3.1.2 Impact of varying KOH amounts on catalytic performance A series of catalysts with varying amounts of KOH were prepared, with KOH-to-activated carbon ratios of 0:100, 5:95, 10:90, 15:85, and 20:80, respectively. The catalytic properties of these catalysts at 210 °C and 190 °C are shown in Figure S1. Under the reaction conditions of 210 °C, it was observed that, except for the Zn5K8–0-4/AC catalyst (which did not contain potassium), the conversion rates of the other four catalysts exceeded 95%. This suggests that high-temperature calcination alone is insufficient to enhance the catalyst's performance and may even result in a decline in catalytic efficiency. In contrast, the catalysts containing potassium consistently demonstrated superior catalytic activity, highlighting the positive effect of potassium on catalytic performance. When the reaction temperature was reduced to 190 °C, the catalytic activity decreased for all catalysts. Interestingly, the conversion rate of methyl formate decomposition exhibited a "volcanic" pattern with respect to potassium content, where the Zn5K8–15–4/AC catalyst exhibited the highest conversion rate of 69.0%. This indicates that there is an optimal amount of potassium for maximizing catalytic activity, and excessive potassium may not further improve the catalyst's performance. 3.1.3 Influence of calcination temperature on catalytic performance after KOH impregnation The calcination temperatures of the catalysts after KOH impregnation were varied, with the selected temperatures being 500, 600, 700, 800, and 900 °C. The catalytic performance of these catalysts was evaluated at reaction temperatures of 210 °C and 190 °C, as shown in Figure S2. At 210 °C, the conversion rate for the Zn5K5-10/AC catalyst was relatively low, at 83.7%, while the conversion rates of the other catalysts were all above 95%. However, when the reaction temperature was lowered to 190 °C, a decrease in catalytic performance was observed for all catalysts, with the conversion rates following a pronounced trend. Among them, Zn5K7-10-4/AC and Zn5K6-10-4/AC exhibited the highest conversion rates, around 70%, which represents the optimal performance in this series at 190 °C. These findings indicate that the calcination temperature significantly influences the catalytic activity, with intermediate calcination temperatures achieving the best compromise between catalytic efficiency and stability. 3.1.4 Effect of calcination time on catalytic activity after KOH impregnation The calcination duration following KOH impregnation also plays a vital role in determining the catalytic performance of the catalysts. The calcination times investigated were 4, 8, 12, 16, and 20 hours. As shown in Figure S3, the catalytic activities of catalysts prepared at these different calcination times were evaluated at two reaction temperatures: 210 °C and 190 °C. At 210 °C, the catalytic performance remained consistently high across all catalysts, with four of them showing conversion rates above 99%, indicating that the calcination time did not significantly affect their catalytic efficiency at this temperature. In contrast, when the reaction temperature was reduced to 190 °C, a noticeable decline in performance was observed. Catalysts calcined for 8, 12, and 16 hours retained good catalytic activity, with conversion rates around 95%. However, the catalyst calcined for 20 hours exhibited a lower conversion rate of 88.4%, suggesting that prolonged calcination may hinder catalytic efficiency, possibly due to the loss of active sites or structural degradation over extended heating times. 3.1.5 Influence of calcination temperature on catalytic activity after zinc loading The effect of calcination temperature after zinc loading on catalytic performance was studied with a fixed calcination time of 16 hours, as shown in Figure S4. At a reaction temperature of 210 °C, the catalytic activity remained relatively stable, with conversion rates consistently above 98%, indicating minimal influence of calcination temperature on performance at this higher temperature. However, when the reaction temperature was lowered to 190 °C, the catalytic performance exhibited a distinct trend, with the conversion rates following a volcano-type pattern. The Zn5K8-10-16/AC catalyst, prepared at 500 °C, exhibited the highest conversion rate of 96.5%. In contrast, the conversion rates of other catalysts decreased sequentially as the calcination temperature increased, suggesting that an optimal calcination temperature exists, which maximizes catalytic activity. This behavior highlights the importance of temperature control during catalyst preparation for enhancing catalytic efficiency, especially at lower reaction temperatures. 3.2 Characterization results and discussion of catalysts 3.2.1 Characterization of catalyst pore structure and the effect of potassium modification The specific surface areas and pore volumes of the catalysts were analyzed using nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms, with the results presented in Table 1 , Fig. 2 , Figure S5, and Figure S6. As shown in the table, the incorporation of potassium led to varying degrees of reduction in both specific surface area and pore volume across the catalysts. This decrease is likely due to the blockage of pores upon potassium addition, which in turn results in a reduction of the specific surface area and a loss of pore structure. However, increasing the amount of KOH during catalyst preparation allowed for some recovery of the specific surface area. This is attributed to the reaction between KOH and AC during the calcination process, where the melting of KOH enhances the formation of micropores and increases the specific surface area of the final carbonaceous structure [18]. Thus, it can be speculated that the KOH modification process involves a competitive interaction between micropore formation and the blockage by potassium species, which affects the specific surface area of the catalyst. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of the catalyst series were classified as type IV according to IUPAC guidelines, indicating that micropores dominate the pore structure of the catalysts. The presence of an H4 hysteresis loop at a relative pressure of 0.4 suggests that the material contains a certain degree of mesoporosity. The pore size distribution graph (Figure S5) reveals that the majority of the pores are within the 2 nm range, while the more detailed pore size distribution (Figure S6) shows that most pores are concentrated in the range of 0.45 to 0.60 nm. These findings provide insight into the porous structure of the catalysts and highlight the influence of potassium modification on their textural properties. 3.2.2 XRD characterization of catalyst phase structures To qualitatively examine the phase structures of the catalysts, a series of samples were analyzed using XRD, with the corresponding spectra shown in Fig. 3 . All the XRD patterns display two broad diffraction peaks around 26° and 44°, which are associated with the carbon skeleton of the AC, corresponding to the (002) and (101) crystal planes of the carbon carrier [19]. Fig. 3a compares the XRD patterns of ZnO/AC [16], K8-10-4/AC, and Zn5K8-10-4/AC samples. The diffraction peaks at 31.4°, 34.4°, and 36.3° in the XRD pattern of ZnO/AC match well with the XRD reference for ZnO (pdf 36–1451), confirming the presence of ZnO crystals in the catalyst [20]. In the K8-10-4/AC sample, diffraction peaks at 24.1°, 30.5°, 31.6°, 34.2°, 38.2°, and 39.3° correspond to potassium bicarbonate, matching the XRD pdf (70–0997). The XRD pattern of Zn5K8-10-4/AC also exhibits a characteristic diffraction peak for potassium bicarbonate, but no clear peaks for ZnO are observed. This suggests that zinc species in the catalyst are highly dispersed and may form a small amount of zinc hydroxide, as indicated by comparison with XRD pdf (20–1435). Fig. 3b shows that the intensity of the diffraction peaks of potassium bicarbonate generally increases with the content of the substance, which suggests an increase in grain size with higher potassium content. In Fig. 3c, as the calcination temperature increases, the diffraction peaks of potassium bicarbonate initially strengthen and then weaken. This pattern indicates that the particle size of potassium bicarbonate increases with temperature up to a certain point, after which it decreases. Fig. 3d and e further demonstrate that as the calcination time increases, the diffraction peak intensity of potassium bicarbonate diminishes. This decrease in peak intensity could be due to the more complete dispersion of potassium species in the carrier with longer calcination times, leading to smaller grain sizes and a weakening of the diffraction signal. These results provide insight into the effect of calcination conditions on the phase structure and particle size distribution of the catalysts, which play a critical role in their catalytic performance. 3.2.3 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis of surface species and electronic states The catalysts were characterized using XPS to investigate the chemical states of the species on their surfaces. Fig. 4 displays the XPS spectra of the Zn 2p region for the series of ZnδKβ-α-γ/AC catalysts. Two prominent peaks, located around 1045 eV and 1022 eV, correspond to the Zn 2p3/2 and Zn 2p1/2 levels, respectively, confirming the presence of zinc in the Zn2+ oxidation state [21]. Fig. 5 presents the O 1s XPS spectra for ZnO/AC and Zn5K8-10-16/AC. The spectra are divided into two distinct components: a peak at approximately 531.8 eV, which is attributed to lattice oxygen, and a peak at around 533.4 eV, corresponding to loosely bound oxygen species such as adsorbed oxygen or water [22]. The data reveal that increasing the amount of KOH and the calcination temperature of potassium activation enhances the proportion of lattice oxygen, while higher calcination temperatures during zinc loading lead to a decrease in lattice oxygen content. In Figure S7, two characteristic peaks near 296 eV and 293 eV are observed, corresponding to the K 2p3/2 and K 2p1/2 states, respectively, indicating the presence of potassium species in the form of K+ [23]. Notably, both the Zn 2p and K 2p peaks shift to varying extents, suggesting that the chemical environment and electron cloud density of zinc and potassium are altered. This shift is likely due to electron transfer or induction effects between the zinc and potassium species (and the support material), leading to changes in the electron density around these sites [24]. Further analysis of the relationship between the surface electronic states and the catalytic properties of the zinc and oxygen species reveals interesting trends. As shown in Fig. 5, the binding energy of Zn 2p exhibits a general trend of high-energy displacement followed by low-energy displacement, with catalysts exhibiting better catalytic performance displaying higher binding energies and lower electron densities on the zinc surface. This observation is consistent with findings from our previous studies [16]. Moreover, in Fig. 5, a noticeable low-energy shift in the binding energy of O 2p after potassium modification can be seen, especially in Fig. 5a-d. This suggests that changes in preparation conditions can modulate the electron cloud density on the surface oxygen species. The decrease in binding energy indicates an increase in the electron density on the oxygen species, leading to a higher negative charge on the surface. According to the literature [11] and the adsorption-desorption volcanic curve theory, it can be inferred that the oxygen species are key sites for the adsorption of the carbonyl group from MF and the desorption of CO. When the electron cloud density is lower, the surface negative charge is weaker, making it difficult to fully adsorb the carbonyl group. Conversely, when the electron cloud density is higher and the negative charge is increased, the binding energy with the carbonyl group strengthens, hindering the desorption of carbon monoxide. This insight highlights the crucial role of surface electron density in optimizing the catalytic performance of these materials. 3.2.4 Characterization of alkaline sites and basicity distribution on catalyst surface To investigate the distribution and strength of alkaline sites, a series of catalysts were analyzed using CO2-temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD). The CO2-TPD profiles, shown in Fig. 6 , reveal three distinct desorption temperature ranges. The desorption peak below 200 °C corresponds to weak alkaline adsorption sites, between 200 °C and 400 °C to medium-strong alkaline sites, and above 400 °C to strong alkaline sites. In Fig. 6a, AC exhibits only weak and medium-strong alkaline adsorption peaks, with a slight enhancement in the desorption peaks of ZnO/AC [16], suggesting a small increase in alkalinity after zinc loading. However, for K8-10-4/AC and Zn5K8-10-4/AC, both the weak and strong alkaline site peak areas increased significantly, indicating a substantial enhancement in basicity compared to AC and ZnO/AC. Among these, Zn5K8-10-4/AC showed the highest basicity. As shown in Fig. 6b, increasing the amount of KOH further increased the overall alkalinity of the catalysts. Fig. 6c highlights that Zn5K5-10-4/AC exhibits the highest number of strong alkaline sites and the fewest weak alkaline sites, while Zn5K9-10-4/AC has the lowest concentration of strong alkaline sites and a higher proportion of medium alkaline sites. These results suggest that varying the KOH dosage can significantly influence the distribution of alkaline sites, which may impact the catalytic performance by altering the nature of the active sites. 3.2.5 In-situ DRIFTS spectroscopic study of MF adsorption on catalysts The in-situ Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform Spectroscopy (DRIFTS) spectra of MF adsorption on the catalysts are presented in Fig. 7 . The spectra display several characteristic peaks at approximately 3700 cm−1, 2900 cm−1, 1750 cm−1, 1600 cm−1, 1350 cm−1, 1200 cm−1, and 1045 cm−1. Specifically, the peak at 3700 cm−1 corresponds to the O-H bond vibration, while the peak at 2900 cm−1 is attributed to the C–H stretching vibration of the –CH3 group. The peak at 1750 cm−1 is associated with the CO bond vibration, and the peak at 1600 cm−1 is linked to the presence of monodentate formate (m-HCOO). The peak at 1350 cm−1 also corresponds to the O–H bond vibration. The peak at 1200 cm−1 is attributed to the C–O–C stretching vibration, and the peak at 1045 cm−1 corresponds to the vibration of methoxy (CH3O) species [25–27]. Based on the intermediate product analysis, it can be inferred that the carbonyl group of MF adsorbs onto the oxygen species of the catalyst and undergoes decomposition into methoxy (CH3O) and formate (HCOO) species via nucleophilic attack by the oxygen species [28,29]. A comparison of the spectral data for the two catalysts reveals that the addition of potassium leads to an increased accumulation of formate species (HCOO). This suggests that the enhanced alkalinity promotes the cleavage of the ester bond in MF, facilitating the formation of more HCOO species. The structure of m-HCOO is relatively unstable and prone to conversion into carbon monoxide (CO) [30], indicating that the presence of potassium not only enhances the catalytic activity but also accelerates the ester bond cleavage, promoting CO formation. This result further emphasizes the role of potassium in modifying the catalyst's basicity and facilitating the decomposition process of MF. 3.3 Stability test and structure change of catalyst 3.3.1 Catalyst stability test: long-term performance of Zn5K8-10-16/AC The stability of the Zn5K8-10-16/AC catalyst, which exhibited the best catalytic performance, was evaluated, and the results are shown in Fig. 8 a. The catalyst demonstrated excellent catalytic activity, maintaining stability for up to 100 hours, which indicates its long-term reliability and robust performance. In contrast, the stability of the K8-10-16/AC catalyst was also investigated over time, as shown in Fig. 8b. While the catalyst initially displayed good catalytic performance within the first 2 hours, rapid deactivation occurred as the reaction progressed, leading to a significant drop-in conversion rate. This suggests that although the K8-10-16/AC catalyst exhibits high initial activity, it suffers from rapid deactivation during prolonged use. Further investigation into the catalytic activity of various potassium-modified catalysts (Kβ-α-γ/AC) over time, as depicted in Fig. 8c, confirmed that rapid deactivation is a common issue for potassium-based catalysts. This phenomenon highlights the inherent instability of potassium catalysts in the decomposition of MF. However, it is noteworthy that the zinc-potassium bimetallic catalyst, Zn5K8-10-16/AC, combines the advantages of both high activity and good stability, addressing the challenge of deactivation and offering a promising solution for the efficient and sustained decomposition of MF. These findings suggest that the combination of zinc and potassium provides a synergistic effect, enhancing both the catalytic performance and long-term stability of the catalyst. 3.3.2 Structural evolution of Zn5K8-10-16/AC catalyst after reaction To investigate the microstructural changes of the catalyst, TEM observations were performed on the Zn5K8-10-16/AC catalyst before and after reaction, accompanied by EDS mapping to analyze the distribution of zinc, potassium, oxygen, and carbon. As shown in Fig. 9 a and c, the fresh catalyst prior to reaction exhibited highly dispersed zinc species on its surface, with a relatively smooth and uniform surface topography. However, after the reaction, significant changes in the catalyst morphology were observed. In Fig. 9b, TEM images revealed the formation of numerous needle-like or rod-shaped particles, which were absent in the fresh catalyst. Further analysis by EDS mapping, shown in Fig. 9d, identified that these needle-like or rod-shaped structures primarily consisted of zinc. In addition, the HAADF-STEM image of the post-reaction catalyst clearly displayed these tiny needle-like particles. EDS mapping confirmed that zinc was concentrated in these particles, indicating that the zinc species, which were initially well-dispersed, had agglomerated during the reaction. These results suggest that the zinc species may have aggregated into short needle-like particles after use, which could be detrimental to the catalytic performance. The agglomeration of active species, such as zinc, can lead to a reduction in the available active sites, thereby adversely affecting the catalytic efficiency. This finding highlights the importance of maintaining the dispersion of active components during catalytic reactions to ensure sustained high performance. 4 Discussion: performance and stability enhancement in zinc-potassium bimetallic catalysts A series of Zn-K bimetallic catalysts were prepared by potassium hydroxide impregnation of AC, and it was found that potassium modification significantly improved the catalytic activity of the catalysts. ZnδKβ-α-γ/AC series catalysts were prepared by adjusting the amount of potassium hydroxide, calcination temperature, time, and zinc loading methods, and their activity was evaluated. Among them, Zn5K8-10-16/AC showed the best activity and maintained good stability over 100 hours of testing. Based on catalytic activity evaluations, characterization data, and literatures, the following conclusions are drawn: 1. Surface Electronic States: XPS characterization revealed that higher binding energy of zinc species corresponds to better catalytic performance. Additionally, the proportion of lattice oxygen and the surface electron cloud density of oxygen species can be controlled by adjusting preparation conditions. An appropriate electron cloud density and the optimal number of negative charges on the surface of oxygen species play a crucial role in the adsorption of methyl formate carbonyl groups and the desorption of carbon monoxide. 2. Phase Structure Analysis: XRD analysis showed that potassium exists in the catalyst as potassium bicarbonate species, while zinc species are highly dispersed in the catalyst and exist as small amounts of zinc hydroxide. The high dispersion of active species contributes to the improvement of catalytic performance. 3. Basic Sites Analysis: CO2-TPD results indicated that the number and strength of basic sites could be regulated by changing preparation conditions, and an appropriate basic strength effectively promotes catalytic performance. 4. Effect of Potassium Introduction: The introduction of potassium enhances the catalyst's alkalinity, which facilitates the cleavage of ester bonds in MF, leading to the formation of more m-HCOO species and further generation of CO. 5 Conclusion In this study, potassium modification significantly enhanced the catalytic performance of zinc oxide-activated carbon (ZnO/AC) catalysts for MF decomposition. The Zn5K8-10-4/AC catalyst achieved an impressive conversion rate of 99.3% at 210 °C. Characterization results revealed that potassium not only improved the conversion rate but also enhanced the catalyst's alkalinity, regulated the electronic states of zinc and oxygen species, and promoted the cleavage of ester bonds in MF. These findings offer valuable insights for the development of efficient catalysts for MF decomposition and for applications such as coal-to-ethylene glycol processes. coredata.dc:description: Methyl formate (MF) decomposition is essential for producing valuable chemicals, but finding efficient and stable catalysts is challenging. This study explores the catalytic performance of ZnO/AC, K8-10-4/AC, and Zn5K8-10-4/AC in MF decomposition. The catalysts were synthesized by varying the potassium-to-carbon ratios and the calcination temperatures and durations, and characterized using nitrogen adsorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), CO2-TPD, and in-situ DRIFTS. Zn5K8-10-4/AC demonstrated significantly higher activity, with a conversion rate of 99.3%, compared to ZnO/AC (18.4%) and K8-10-4/AC (2.4%) at 210 °C. Potassium addition enhanced the basicity and surface properties, facilitating ester bond cleavage and HCOO species formation. Zn5K8-10-16/AC also exhibited excellent stability over 100 hours, in contrast to the rapid deactivation observed with K8-10-16/AC. This study highlights the synergistic effect of zinc and potassium for improving catalytic performance and stability, offering insights for designing more efficient catalysts for MF decomposition and similar reactions.
